◆ bcm_port_link_failed_clear()

int bcm_port_link_failed_clear ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port 
)

Clear failed link status from a port which has undergone LAG failover.

This function clears the BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_FAILED state from a port which has transitioned into LAG failover. The port is moved to the BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_DOWN state. The application is responsible for removing the port from trunk membership before calling this function. Linkscan (see Link Monitoring and Notification) must be running to use LAG failover.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number

◆ bcm_port_link_state_get()

int bcm_port_link_state_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
uint32  flags,
bcm_port_link_state_t *  state 
)

Retrieve the current link state of a port.

This call returns the link state of the port. With linkscan running (see Link Monitoring and Notification ), the current link status is retrieved from the linkscan task. This is the normal mode of operation, as link status in the PHY registers is latched low. If multiple sources (threads) read the physical link status in the PHY register, the linkscan task and/or applications can miss a link down event. If linkscan is not running, the current link status is retrieved from the PHY directly. Once the call to bcm_port_link_state_get has been made, latch_down will be cleared. The possible values of status are as shown in BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_m

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number.
[in]flagsFlags to be used in while getting port state
[out]stateRetieved port state, including port status and latch_down.
typedef struct bcm_port_link_state_s {
int status; // link status, one of BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_*
int latch_down; // indicates whether link latch has been down since last call to API.
} bcm_port_link_state_t;

◆ bcm_port_link_status_get()

int bcm_port_link_status_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int *  status 
)

Retrieve the current link status of a port.

This call returns the link status of the port. With linkscan running (see Link Monitoring and Notification ), the current link status is retrieved from the linkscan task. This is the normal mode of operation, as link status in the PHY registers is latched low. If multiple sources (threads) read the physical link status in the PHY register, the linkscan task and/or applications can miss a link down event. If linkscan is not running, the current link status is retrieved from the PHY directly. The possible values of status are:

Link Status States
Status Description
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_DOWN The PHY link is down, or a remote fault condition was previously noted.
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_UP The PHY link is up and no remote fault is signaled.
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_FAILED The port was configured for LAG failover, which has triggered. This state requires application intervention via bcm_port_link_failed_clear . Only available when linkscan is running.
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_REMOTE_FAULT The port has detected a new remote fault condition. This status will only be indicated to a link notification handler enabled through bcm_linkscan_register . It is equivalent to link down status for all other purposes.
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_LOCAL_FAULT The port has detected a new local fault condition. This status will only be indicated to a link notification handler enabled through bcm_linkscan_register . It is equivalent to link down status for all other purposes.
BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_LOCAL_AND_REMOTE_FAULT The port has detected both a new local fault and a new remote fault condition. This status will only be indicated to a link notification handler enabled through bcm_linkscan_register . It is equivalent to link down status for all other purposes.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number.
[out]statusOne of BCM_PORT_LINK_STATUS_*.

◆ bcm_port_linkscan_get()

int bcm_port_linkscan_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int *  linkscan 
)

Get or set the current linkscan mode for the specified port.

Link scanning is performed by the linkscan task ( Link Monitoring and Notification). For the BCM interface, these functions are equivalent to functions bcm_linkscan_mode_set and bcm_linkscan_mode_set .

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[out]linkscanLinkscan mode, see table BCM_LINKSCAN_MODE_e

◆ bcm_port_linkscan_set()

int bcm_port_linkscan_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int  linkscan 
)

Get or set the current linkscan mode for the specified port.

Link scanning is performed by the linkscan task ( Link Monitoring and Notification). For the BCM interface, these functions are equivalent to functions bcm_linkscan_mode_set and bcm_linkscan_mode_set .

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]linkscanLinkscan mode, see table BCM_LINKSCAN_MODE_e

◆ bcm_port_local_get()

int bcm_port_local_get ( int  unit,
bcm_gport_t  gport,
bcm_port_t *  local_port 
)

Get local port number encoded within a GPORT ID.

This API can be used to get a local port number encoded into a GPORT ID. This resulting port number will return FALSE on a BCM_GPORT_IS_SET(port) test. To encode the result as a local port gport ID, use BCM_GPORT_LOCAL_SET(gport_local, local_port); If the encoding of GPORT ID does not contain a local port on a device, this API will return an error. GPORT ID may be encoded as both MODPORT and DEVPORT.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]gportGPORT ID
[out]local_portLocal port number

◆ bcm_port_loopback_get()

int bcm_port_loopback_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int *  loopback 
)

Set or retrieve the current loopback mode of a port.

Depending on the capabilities of a port, the port may be configured to operate in MAC loopback, PHY loopback or no loopback. No loopback is the normal operating mode for a device. The external configuration of a port may not support PHY loopback in some cases. To verify a port can support the desired loopback mode, the API call bcm_port_ability_get may be called. A port successfully configured in loopback mode is considered to have link. Transitioning into, out of, and between loopback modes all force Link Monitoring and Notification to recognize link events. Valid modes are described in BCM_PORT_LB_m .

Loopback Modes
Mode Description
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_NONE No loopback mode, normal for operation
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_MAC MAC loopback mode, packets egressing the port will be looped back internal to the MAC.
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_PHY PHY loopback mode, packets egressing the port will be looped back at the external PHY.
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_PHY_REMOTE PHY remote loopback mode, packets injecting to the port will be looped back to the sender.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portPort for which the loopback mode is being set or retrieved
[out]loopbackSpecifies the loopback mode; see table BCM_PORT_LB_m for values

◆ bcm_port_loopback_set()

int bcm_port_loopback_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int  loopback 
)

Set or retrieve the current loopback mode of a port.

Depending on the capabilities of a port, the port may be configured to operate in MAC loopback, PHY loopback or no loopback. No loopback is the normal operating mode for a device. The external configuration of a port may not support PHY loopback in some cases. To verify a port can support the desired loopback mode, the API call bcm_port_ability_get may be called. A port successfully configured in loopback mode is considered to have link. Transitioning into, out of, and between loopback modes all force Link Monitoring and Notification to recognize link events. Valid modes are described in BCM_PORT_LB_m .

Loopback Modes
Mode Description
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_NONE No loopback mode, normal for operation
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_MAC MAC loopback mode, packets egressing the port will be looped back internal to the MAC.
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_PHY PHY loopback mode, packets egressing the port will be looped back at the external PHY.
BCM_PORT_LOOPBACK_PHY_REMOTE PHY remote loopback mode, packets injecting to the port will be looped back to the sender.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portPort for which the loopback mode is being set or retrieved
[in]loopbackSpecifies the loopback mode; see table BCM_PORT_LB_m for values

◆ bcm_port_management_packet_config_get()

int bcm_port_management_packet_config_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_management_packet_config_t *  config_array,
int  max_config,
int *  config_count 
)

Get or set the management packet classification properties.

XGS devices like BCM88732 provide a mechanism to classify frames based on Destination MAC address or EtherType or combination of Destination MAC Address and EtherType as a special frame, called management frames. The purpose of this classification is to assign a priority and drop precedence to such frames and queue them to certain CoS Queues for loss-less or strict priority processing. The bcm_port_management_packet_config_set API provides the user to configure destination MAC address and/or EtherType for management frame classification. The flags member of the bcm_port_management_packet_config_t input parameter specifies the valid members of the structure. To clear the Management classification configuration, the bcm_port_management_packet_config_set may be used with the Destination MAC address and/or EtherType. The flag must be OR'ed with BCM_PORT_MANAGEMENT_PACKET_CLEAR to indicate the clear operation. The management frame configuration can be retrieved by using the bcm_port_management_packet_config_get API. The user must pass a pointer to non-null array to structure bcm_port_management_packet_config_t. The number of elements that are requested should be set in max_config (this count reflects the memory allocated to the config structure). The API returns the actual number of currently set management frame classification configuration.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice port number or logical device
[in]config_arrayManagement Packet Configuration Structure.
[in]max_configManagement Packet Configuration Structure Array size.
[out]config_count

◆ bcm_port_management_packet_config_set()

int bcm_port_management_packet_config_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_management_packet_config_t *  config 
)

Get or set the management packet classification properties.

XGS devices like BCM88732 provide a mechanism to classify frames based on Destination MAC address or EtherType or combination of Destination MAC Address and EtherType as a special frame, called management frames. The purpose of this classification is to assign a priority and drop precedence to such frames and queue them to certain CoS Queues for loss-less or strict priority processing. The bcm_port_management_packet_config_set API provides the user to configure destination MAC address and/or EtherType for management frame classification. The flags member of the bcm_port_management_packet_config_t input parameter specifies the valid members of the structure. To clear the Management classification configuration, the bcm_port_management_packet_config_set may be used with the Destination MAC address and/or EtherType. The flag must be OR'ed with BCM_PORT_MANAGEMENT_PACKET_CLEAR to indicate the clear operation. The management frame configuration can be retrieved by using the bcm_port_management_packet_config_get API. The user must pass a pointer to non-null array to structure bcm_port_management_packet_config_t. The number of elements that are requested should be set in max_config (this count reflects the memory allocated to the config structure). The API returns the actual number of currently set management frame classification configuration.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice port number or logical device
[in]configPointer to bcm_port_management_packet_config_t.

◆ bcm_port_mapping_info_t_init()

void bcm_port_mapping_info_t_init ( bcm_port_mapping_info_t *  mapping)

Initialize structure bcm_port_mapping_info_t.

Parameters
[out]mappingport mapping information

◆ bcm_port_master_get()

int bcm_port_master_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int *  ms 
)

Set or get the Master mode on the PHY attached to the specified port.

Master Mode Values
BCM_PORT_MS_SLAVE Configure port or port is configured in SLAVE mode.
BCM_PORT_MS_MASTER Configure port or port is configured in MASTER mode.
BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO Configure port for (or port is configured for) automatic master port selection.
BCM_PORT_MS_NONE Port does not support forced master mode selection.

For PHYs that support master mode selection, force the mode to the specified value or retrieve the current operating mode. This function should be used for diagnostic and testing purposes only. By default, those ports that support master and slave mode are placed in the mode BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO allowing the PHY to determine the correct mode based on auto-negotiation. Broadcom PHYs require auto-negotiation be enabled for automatic master mode selection, for more information see bcm_port_autoneg_set . Ports that do not support master and slave mode return BCM_PORT_MS_NONE when queried and silently ignore attempts to configure the mode. Master mode is supported only on gigabit copper interfaces.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice port number or logical port number.
[out]msMaster mode selection, see table MS_TABLE .

◆ bcm_port_master_set()

int bcm_port_master_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
int  ms 
)

Set or get the Master mode on the PHY attached to the specified port.

Master Mode Values
BCM_PORT_MS_SLAVE Configure port or port is configured in SLAVE mode.
BCM_PORT_MS_MASTER Configure port or port is configured in MASTER mode.
BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO Configure port for (or port is configured for) automatic master port selection.
BCM_PORT_MS_NONE Port does not support forced master mode selection.

For PHYs that support master mode selection, force the mode to the specified value or retrieve the current operating mode. This function should be used for diagnostic and testing purposes only. By default, those ports that support master and slave mode are placed in the mode BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO allowing the PHY to determine the correct mode based on auto-negotiation. Broadcom PHYs require auto-negotiation be enabled for automatic master mode selection, for more information see bcm_port_autoneg_set . Ports that do not support master and slave mode return BCM_PORT_MS_NONE when queried and silently ignore attempts to configure the mode. Master mode is supported only on gigabit copper interfaces.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice port number or logical port number.
[in]msMaster mode selection, see table MS_TABLE .

◆ bcm_port_match_add()

int bcm_port_match_add ( int  unit,
bcm_gport_t  port,
bcm_port_match_info_t *  match 
)

Add a match to an existing virtual port, or add multiple matches to a shared virtual port and also gports such as Mirror destination ID.

This API adds a match criterion to an existing virtual port, or add multiple matches to a shared virtual port and also gports such as Mirror destination ID. The virtual port must be created first.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portVirtual port GPORT ID
[in]matchMatch criteria
Return values
BCM_E_XXX

◆ bcm_port_match_delete()

◆ bcm_port_match_info_t_init()

void bcm_port_match_info_t_init ( bcm_port_match_info_t *  port_match_info)

Initialize a Port Match Information structure.

Initializes a port match information structure to default values. This function should be used to initialize any Port Match Information structure prior to filling it out and passing it to an API function. This ensures that the structure is initialized to correct default values on subsequent API releases that may add new members to the structure.

Parameters
[in,out]port_match_info(IN/OUT) Pointer to Port Match Information structure to initialize.
Return values
NONE.

◆ bcm_port_match_multi_get()

int bcm_port_match_multi_get ( int  unit,
bcm_gport_t  port,
int  size,
bcm_port_match_info_t *  match_array,
int *  count 
)

Get all the matches for an existing port.

This API retrieves match criteria for an existing virtual port. Setting size to zero, retrieves the count. The virtual port must be created first.

Parameters

[in]portVirtual port GPORT ID
[in]sizeNumber of elements in match array
[out]match_arrayMatch array
[out]countMatch count
Return values
BCM_E_XXX

◆ bcm_port_mdix_get()

int bcm_port_mdix_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_mdix_t *  mode 
)

Get or set the Auto MDIX mode for a port.

Auto-MDIX is a PHY function that allows for the detection and internal correction for improper use of cross over cables. This function is not available on all PHYs. Valid port mdix modes are described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_e and valid port MDIX status is described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_e . bcm_port_mdix_set and bcm_port_mdix_get set or get the configured mode of operation. bcm_port_mdix_status_get retrieves the current MDIX status. If the current mode is BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO or BCM_PORT_MDIX_FRCE_AUTO this call can be used to determine whether or not MDIX is actively compensating for a crossed over connect. Results are undefined if there is no link active.

BCM Port MDIX Modes
Mode Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX when auto-negotiation is enabled
BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX always, regardless of the auto-negotiation setting.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to normal.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to crossed over.

BCM Port MDIX Status
Status Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_NORMAL Port is operating in a normal mode, that is, it is not crossed over.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUX_XOVER Port is currently operating in a cross over mode.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[out]modeOperating mode requested or retrieved (see BCM_PORT_MDIX_e)

◆ bcm_port_mdix_set()

int bcm_port_mdix_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_mdix_t  mode 
)

Get or set the Auto MDIX mode for a port.

Auto-MDIX is a PHY function that allows for the detection and internal correction for improper use of cross over cables. This function is not available on all PHYs. Valid port mdix modes are described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_e and valid port MDIX status is described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_e . bcm_port_mdix_set and bcm_port_mdix_get set or get the configured mode of operation. bcm_port_mdix_status_get retrieves the current MDIX status. If the current mode is BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO or BCM_PORT_MDIX_FRCE_AUTO this call can be used to determine whether or not MDIX is actively compensating for a crossed over connect. Results are undefined if there is no link active.

BCM Port MDIX Modes
Mode Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX when auto-negotiation is enabled
BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX always, regardless of the auto-negotiation setting.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to normal.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to crossed over.

BCM Port MDIX Status
Status Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_NORMAL Port is operating in a normal mode, that is, it is not crossed over.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUX_XOVER Port is currently operating in a cross over mode.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]modeOperating mode requested or retrieved (see BCM_PORT_MDIX_e)

◆ bcm_port_mdix_status_get()

int bcm_port_mdix_status_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_mdix_status_t *  status 
)

Get or set the Auto MDIX mode for a port.

Auto-MDIX is a PHY function that allows for the detection and internal correction for improper use of cross over cables. This function is not available on all PHYs. Valid port mdix modes are described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_e and valid port MDIX status is described in table BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_e . bcm_port_mdix_set and bcm_port_mdix_get set or get the configured mode of operation. bcm_port_mdix_status_get retrieves the current MDIX status. If the current mode is BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO or BCM_PORT_MDIX_FRCE_AUTO this call can be used to determine whether or not MDIX is actively compensating for a crossed over connect. Results are undefined if there is no link active.

BCM Port MDIX Modes
Mode Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX when auto-negotiation is enabled
BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO Enable auto-MDIX always, regardless of the auto-negotiation setting.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to normal.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER Disable auto-MDIX, force mode to crossed over.

BCM Port MDIX Status
Status Meaning
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_NORMAL Port is operating in a normal mode, that is, it is not crossed over.
BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUX_XOVER Port is currently operating in a cross over mode.
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[out]statusCurrent operating status (see BCM_PORT_MDIX_STATUS_e )

◆ bcm_port_medium_config_get()

int bcm_port_medium_config_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_medium_t  medium,
bcm_phy_config_t *  config 
)

Get or set medium preferences for combination ports.

Combination (combo) ports are those that supports more than one medium type, such as copper and fiber, on the same switch port. Of course, only one medium type may be active at a time because they share the same switch port. The BCM5421S, BCM5461S, and BCM5464S are PHYs that supports copper/fiber combo ports. Boards using these PHYs can be built with gigabit ports that simultaneously have an RJ-45 and fiber module, or an RJ-45 and a GBIC. These PHYs also support automatic detection of signal/energy on each medium. A user can plug or unplug either medium type and the PHY (and software driver) can automatically switch the medium type. In case both medium types are active, one medium is selected based on a configurable priority, the default being fiber. Automatic medium selection is optional. Ports may also be forced to one mode or the other by the application using the API calls to disable the inactive medium (this enable value is provided in the bcm_phy_config_t shown in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t). Medium selection can be programmed such that:

  • If only the copper side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up copper.
  • If only the fiber side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up fiber.
  • If both sides are plugged in, only the medium that is configured as the 'preferred medium' (see below) will link up.
  • If fiber is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the copper side will not have any effect on the fiber side.
  • If copper is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the fiber side will not have any effect on the copper side. Several driver run-time configuration properties exist that can be used to set the default medium auto detection mode, preferred medium, and other aspects of default behavior. Certain situations may result in link behavior that does not seem intuitive, but is unavoidable. These cases are:
  • In Auto Medium mode with Fiber Preferred, when fiber link is active the copper TX is powered down to prevent false link on copper remote link partner.
  • When the fiber link is inactive, both fiber and copper TX are enabled to permit selection of interface that has receive energy. This allows connection between two Auto Medium combo ports. Medium selection is based on receive energy, and the link partner TX provides this. To enable an Auto Medium combo port to connect properly to another Auto Medium combo port, the TX energy to the remote link must be active.
  • Fiber TX energy is always active to permit an Auto Medium combo port to connect to another Auto Medium combo port.
  • In Auto Medium mode with Copper Preferred, when the copper link is active the fiber auto-negotiation is not active. This prevents false link on the fiber remote link partner. However, the fiber TX may provide energy to remote link partner and result in false link if auto-negotiation is disabled on remote link partner.
  • When the copper link is inactive, both fiber and copper TX are enabled to permit selection of interface that has receive energy. The BCM5464 will be in pass-through mode to permit fiber interface to perform auto-negotiation. This allows connection between two Auto Medium combo ports. Medium selection is based on receive energy, and the link partner TX provides this. To enable an Auto Medium combo port to connect properly to another Auto Medium combo port, the TX from the remote partner should be active.
  • Copper TX energy is always active to permit an Auto Medium combo port to connect to another Auto Medium combo port.
  • In copper forced mode the fiber interface should be inactive. However, a fiber link partner with auto-negotiation disabled may still see link up due to energy provided by the fiber interface.
  • In Fiber forced mode, only the fiber interface is active. The copper TX is powered down to prevent false link up on copper link partner. Medium Configuration Parameters that may be get or set via the bcm_phy_config_t structure described in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t .
    bcm_phy_config_t
    Field Type Description
    enable int PHY enable state
    preferred int True if the medium is the preferred one
    autoneg_enable int Autoneg enable state
    autoneg_advert unsigned int Advertisement values for when autoneg is enabled
    force_speed int Forced speed for when autoneg is disabled
    force_duplex int Forced duplex for when autoneg is disabled
    master int Master/slave mode for 1000TX
    mdix BCM_PORT_MDIX_e Auto-MDIX setting
    Combo PHY drivers keep one set of configuration parameters per medium type. When the bcm_port API call outs, are used on a combo port, only the set of parameters for the active medium are updated. The API functions bcm_port_medium_config_set and bcm_port_medium_config_get can be used to retrieve, modify, and write back this set of parameters, on a per-medium-type basis. For best operation, it is recommended that the caller use bcm_port_medium_config_get(), then update the required fields in the configuration structure, then use bcm_port_medium_config_set(). This API will update the parameters for a specified medium even if the medium is not active. If the active medium is updated, the changes will take effect immediately, which may cause auto-negotiation to restart. It is not necessary to deal with the parameters for multiple medium types if not desired. Instead, a medium change callback can be installed using the bcm_port_medium_status_register()/unregister() API calls to be notified of a change in medium type. The callback occurs after the saved parameters are restored to the PHY, hence the user's callback routine may overwrite any of the parameters if any changes are needed. The medium types are shown in BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_t :
    bcm_port_medium_t
    Medium Description
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_NONE No interface active (get only)
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER Copper interface
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER Fiber interface
    The current medium in use can be determined using bcm_port_medium_get. It is also available in the BCM_PORT_INFO_t structure that is retrieved using bcm_port_info_get . The current medium is also available on each link up event, in the bcm_port_info_t structure that is passed to callback routines registered with the linkscan task via bcm_linkscan_register(). The medium configuration parameters for a specified port and medium type may be retrieved all at once using bcm_port_medium_config_get. The following example shows the current combination port status:
    // Function: sample_combo_dump Purpose: Dump information about a combination port Parameters: unit - BCM device number port - Device port number medium - Medium to display information on, one of BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER or BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER. Returns: 0 - Success -1 - Failed
    int
    sample_combo_dump(int unit, bcm_port_t port, int medium)
    {
    char *m_str, *cm_str, *md_str;
    bcm_port_medium_t active_medium;
    bcm_phy_config_t cfg;
    int r;
    // * Get active medium to put an asterisk next to the status if * it is active.
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_get(u, p, &active_medium)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_config_get(u, p, medium, &cfg)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    // * Format values into strings for display. Done with switch statements to * ensure compatibility with future API releases.
    switch(medium) {
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER: m_str = "Copper"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER: m_str = "Fiber"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.master) {
    case BCM_PORT_MS_SLAVE: cm_str = "Slave"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_MASTER: cm_str = "Master"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO: cm_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_NONE: cm_str = "None"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.mdix) {
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO: md_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO: md_str = "ForceAuto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL: md_str = "ForceNormal"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER: md_str = "ForceXOver"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    printf("Port %d: medium=%s %s
    ", port, m_str,
    (medium == active_medium) ? " (active)" : """);
    printf("enable=%d preferred=%d force_speed=%d force_duplex=%d master=%s
    ",
    cfg.enable, cfg.preferred, cfg.force_speed, cfg.force_duplex, cm_str);
    printf("autoneg_enable=%d mdix=%s
    ", cfg.autoneg_enable, md_str);
    return 0;
    }
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]mediumPHY medium configuration, see BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_t
[out]configPHY configuration, see BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t

◆ bcm_port_medium_config_set()

int bcm_port_medium_config_set ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_medium_t  medium,
bcm_phy_config_t *  config 
)

Get or set medium preferences for combination ports.

Combination (combo) ports are those that supports more than one medium type, such as copper and fiber, on the same switch port. Of course, only one medium type may be active at a time because they share the same switch port. The BCM5421S, BCM5461S, and BCM5464S are PHYs that supports copper/fiber combo ports. Boards using these PHYs can be built with gigabit ports that simultaneously have an RJ-45 and fiber module, or an RJ-45 and a GBIC. These PHYs also support automatic detection of signal/energy on each medium. A user can plug or unplug either medium type and the PHY (and software driver) can automatically switch the medium type. In case both medium types are active, one medium is selected based on a configurable priority, the default being fiber. Automatic medium selection is optional. Ports may also be forced to one mode or the other by the application using the API calls to disable the inactive medium (this enable value is provided in the bcm_phy_config_t shown in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t). Medium selection can be programmed such that:

  • If only the copper side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up copper.
  • If only the fiber side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up fiber.
  • If both sides are plugged in, only the medium that is configured as the 'preferred medium' (see below) will link up.
  • If fiber is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the copper side will not have any effect on the fiber side.
  • If copper is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the fiber side will not have any effect on the copper side. Several driver run-time configuration properties exist that can be used to set the default medium auto detection mode, preferred medium, and other aspects of default behavior. Certain situations may result in link behavior that does not seem intuitive, but is unavoidable. These cases are:
  • In Auto Medium mode with Fiber Preferred, when fiber link is active the copper TX is powered down to prevent false link on copper remote link partner.
  • When the fiber link is inactive, both fiber and copper TX are enabled to permit selection of interface that has receive energy. This allows connection between two Auto Medium combo ports. Medium selection is based on receive energy, and the link partner TX provides this. To enable an Auto Medium combo port to connect properly to another Auto Medium combo port, the TX energy to the remote link must be active.
  • Fiber TX energy is always active to permit an Auto Medium combo port to connect to another Auto Medium combo port.
  • In Auto Medium mode with Copper Preferred, when the copper link is active the fiber auto-negotiation is not active. This prevents false link on the fiber remote link partner. However, the fiber TX may provide energy to remote link partner and result in false link if auto-negotiation is disabled on remote link partner.
  • When the copper link is inactive, both fiber and copper TX are enabled to permit selection of interface that has receive energy. The BCM5464 will be in pass-through mode to permit fiber interface to perform auto-negotiation. This allows connection between two Auto Medium combo ports. Medium selection is based on receive energy, and the link partner TX provides this. To enable an Auto Medium combo port to connect properly to another Auto Medium combo port, the TX from the remote partner should be active.
  • Copper TX energy is always active to permit an Auto Medium combo port to connect to another Auto Medium combo port.
  • In copper forced mode the fiber interface should be inactive. However, a fiber link partner with auto-negotiation disabled may still see link up due to energy provided by the fiber interface.
  • In Fiber forced mode, only the fiber interface is active. The copper TX is powered down to prevent false link up on copper link partner. Medium Configuration Parameters that may be get or set via the bcm_phy_config_t structure described in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t .
    bcm_phy_config_t
    Field Type Description
    enable int PHY enable state
    preferred int True if the medium is the preferred one
    autoneg_enable int Autoneg enable state
    autoneg_advert unsigned int Advertisement values for when autoneg is enabled
    force_speed int Forced speed for when autoneg is disabled
    force_duplex int Forced duplex for when autoneg is disabled
    master int Master/slave mode for 1000TX
    mdix BCM_PORT_MDIX_e Auto-MDIX setting
    Combo PHY drivers keep one set of configuration parameters per medium type. When the bcm_port API call outs, are used on a combo port, only the set of parameters for the active medium are updated. The API functions bcm_port_medium_config_set and bcm_port_medium_config_get can be used to retrieve, modify, and write back this set of parameters, on a per-medium-type basis.     bcm_port_medium_t
    Medium Description
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_NONE No interface active (get only)
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER Copper interface
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER Fiber interface
    The current medium in use can be determined using bcm_port_medium_get. It is also available in the BCM_PORT_INFO_t structure that is retrieved using bcm_port_info_get . The following example shows the current combination port status:

    int
    sample_combo_dump(int unit, bcm_port_t port, int medium)
    {
    char *m_str, *cm_str, *md_str;
    bcm_port_medium_t active_medium;
    bcm_phy_config_t cfg;
    int r;
    // * Get active medium to put an asterisk next to the status if * it is active.
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_get(u, p, &active_medium)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_config_get(u, p, medium, &cfg)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    // * Format values into strings for display. Done with switch statements to * ensure compatibility with future API releases.
    switch(medium) {
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER: m_str = "Copper"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER: m_str = "Fiber"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.master) {
    case BCM_PORT_MS_SLAVE: cm_str = "Slave"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_MASTER: cm_str = "Master"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO: cm_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_NONE: cm_str = "None"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.mdix) {
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO: md_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO: md_str = "ForceAuto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL: md_str = "ForceNormal"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER: md_str = "ForceXOver"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    printf("Port %d: medium=%s %s
    ", port, m_str,
    (medium == active_medium) ? " (active)" : """);
    printf("enable=%d preferred=%d force_speed=%d force_duplex=%d master=%s
    ",
    cfg.enable, cfg.preferred, cfg.force_speed, cfg.force_duplex, cm_str);
    printf("autoneg_enable=%d mdix=%s
    ", cfg.autoneg_enable, md_str);
    return 0;
    }
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]mediumPHY medium configuration, see BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_t
[in]configPHY configuration, see BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t

◆ bcm_port_medium_get()

int bcm_port_medium_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_medium_t *  medium 
)

Get or set medium preferences for combination ports.

Combination (combo) ports are those that supports more than one medium type, such as copper and fiber, on the same switch port. Of course, only one medium type may be active at a time because they share the same switch port. The BCM5421S, BCM5461S, and BCM5464S are PHYs that supports copper/fiber combo ports. Boards using these PHYs can be built with gigabit ports that simultaneously have an RJ-45 and fiber module, or an RJ-45 and a GBIC. These PHYs also support automatic detection of signal/energy on each medium. A user can plug or unplug either medium type and the PHY (and software driver) can automatically switch the medium type. In case both medium types are active, one medium is selected based on a configurable priority, the default being fiber. Automatic medium selection is optional. Ports may also be forced to one mode or the other by the application using the API calls to disable the inactive medium (this enable value is provided in the bcm_phy_config_t shown in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t). Medium selection can be programmed such that:

  • If only the copper side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up copper.
  • If only the fiber side is plugged in, the combo port driver will detect it and link up fiber.
  • If both sides are plugged in, only the medium that is configured as the 'preferred medium' (see below) will link up.
  • If fiber is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the copper side will not have any effect on the fiber side.
  • If copper is the preferred medium and linked up, then plugging and unplugging the fiber side will not have any effect on the copper side. Several driver run-time configuration properties exist that can be used to set the default medium auto detection mode, preferred medium, and other aspects of default behavior.   • When the fiber link is inactive, both fiber and copper TX are enabled to permit selection of interface that has receive energy. This allows connection between two Auto Medium combo ports.   • Copper TX energy is always active to permit an Auto Medium combo port to connect to another Auto Medium combo port.
  • In copper forced mode the fiber interface should be inactive. However, a fiber link partner with auto-negotiation disabled may still see link up due to energy provided by the fiber interface.
  • In Fiber forced mode, only the fiber interface is active. The copper TX is powered down to prevent false link up on copper link partner. Medium Configuration Parameters that may be get or set via the bcm_phy_config_t structure described in BCM_PHY_CONFIG_t .
    bcm_phy_config_t
    Field Type Description
    enable int PHY enable state
    preferred int True if the medium is the preferred one
    autoneg_enable int Autoneg enable state
    autoneg_advert unsigned int Advertisement values for when autoneg is enabled
    force_speed int Forced speed for when autoneg is disabled
    force_duplex int Forced duplex for when autoneg is disabled
    master int Master/slave mode for 1000TX
    mdix BCM_PORT_MDIX_e Auto-MDIX setting

    bcm_port_medium_t
    Medium Description
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_NONE No interface active (get only)
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER Copper interface
    BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER Fiber interface
    The current medium in use can be determined using bcm_port_medium_get. It is also available in the BCM_PORT_INFO_t structure that is retrieved using bcm_port_info_get . The current medium is also available on each link up event, in the bcm_port_info_t structure that is passed to callback routines registered with the linkscan task via bcm_linkscan_register(). The medium configuration parameters for a specified port and medium type may be retrieved all at once using bcm_port_medium_config_get. The following example shows the current combination port status:
    // Function: sample_combo_dump Purpose: Dump information about a combination port Parameters: unit - BCM device number port - Device port number medium - Medium to display information on, one of BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER or BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER. Returns: 0 - Success -1 - Failed
    int
    sample_combo_dump(int unit, bcm_port_t port, int medium)
    {
    char *m_str, *cm_str, *md_str;
    bcm_port_medium_t active_medium;
    bcm_phy_config_t cfg;
    int r;
    // * Get active medium to put an asterisk next to the status if * it is active.
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_get(u, p, &active_medium)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    if ((r = bcm_port_medium_config_get(u, p, medium, &cfg)) < 0) {
    return -1;
    }
    // * Format values into strings for display. Done with switch statements to * ensure compatibility with future API releases.
    switch(medium) {
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_COPPER: m_str = "Copper"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_FIBER: m_str = "Fiber"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.master) {
    case BCM_PORT_MS_SLAVE: cm_str = "Slave"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_MASTER: cm_str = "Master"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_AUTO: cm_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MS_NONE: cm_str = "None"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    switch(cfg.mdix) {
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_AUTO: md_str = "Auto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_FORCE_AUTO: md_str = "ForceAuto"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_NORMAL: md_str = "ForceNormal"; break;
    case BCM_PORT_MDIX_XOVER: md_str = "ForceXOver"; break;
    default: return -1;
    }
    printf("Port %d: medium=%s %s
    ", port, m_str,
    (medium == active_medium) ? " (active)" : """);
    printf("enable=%d preferred=%d force_speed=%d force_duplex=%d master=%s
    ",
    cfg.enable, cfg.preferred, cfg.force_speed, cfg.force_duplex, cm_str);
    printf("autoneg_enable=%d mdix=%s
    ", cfg.autoneg_enable, md_str);
    return 0;
    }
Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[out]mediumPHY medium configuration, see BCM_PORT_MEDIUM_t

◆ bcm_port_medium_status_register()

int bcm_port_medium_status_register ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_medium_status_cb_t  callback,
void *  user_data 
)

Register or unregister a callback function on media status changes.

A callback is available for when the active medium type changes. Whenever the active medium type changes, the configuration parameters for the new medium type are written to the PHY, and then the callback (if any) is made. If desired, this callback could be used to reprogram port parameters (via the bcm_port API) and potentially override the values written from the medium configuration structure. In fact, the entire concept of multiple sets of parameters per medium could be ignored, although it is not preferred. The problem is that a medium may link up after the medium change, but before the application is notified via callback. The link then may move back down and up when the application adjusts the parameters. The callback and user_arg must also match when unregistering. Only one function may be registered at a time.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]callbackFunction to call when a media change is detected on the port
[in]user_dataArbitrary user cookie passed to the callback function when invoked.
Return values
BCM_E_NONE
BCM_E_PARAMNULL function pointer or invalid unit or port
BCM_E_FULLCallback already registered, only one permitted

◆ bcm_port_medium_status_unregister()

int bcm_port_medium_status_unregister ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_port_medium_status_cb_t  callback,
void *  user_data 
)

Register or unregister a callback function on media status changes.

A callback is available for when the active medium type changes. Whenever the active medium type changes, the configuration parameters for the new medium type are written to the PHY, and then the callback (if any) is made. If desired, this callback could be used to reprogram port parameters (via the bcm_port API) and potentially override the values written from the medium configuration structure. In fact, the entire concept of multiple sets of parameters per medium could be ignored, although it is not preferred. The problem is that a medium may link up after the medium change, but before the application is notified via callback. The link then may move back down and up when the application adjusts the parameters. The callback and user_arg must also match when unregistering. Only one function may be registered at a time.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical port number
[in]callbackFunction to call when a media change is detected on the port
[in]user_dataArbitrary user cookie passed to the callback function when invoked.
Return values
BCM_E_NONE
BCM_E_PARAMNULL function pointer or invalid unit or port
BCM_E_FULLCallback already registered, only one permitted

◆ bcm_port_modid_egress_get()

int bcm_port_modid_egress_get ( int  unit,
bcm_port_t  port,
bcm_module_t  modid,
bcm_pbmp_t *  pbmp 
)

Configure which egress ports a stacking port is permitted to forward packets to.

This API controls which local ports packets originating on a specific module are allowed to be forwarded to.

Parameters
[in]unitUnit number.
[in]portDevice or logical stacking port number.
[in]modidModule ID of the source ports to configure.
[out]pbmpBitmaps of ports on the device.
